elt.selection: I was carefully reared by parents who had been slaves, attended public schools
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was carefully reared by parents who had</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">been slaves, attended public schools</tspan>,
removed to Ohio and attended high school.

elt.selection: Mother and father were honest tho unlettered
lines: I was born and reared on a cotton farm. My
early training was such as could be received
in an ex-slave home and three-months-in-the
year school.<tspan class="underline"> Mother and father were</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">honest tho unlettered </tspan>and strove to make
the best of their opportunities and left
that impression upon their children. Best
of all, I was reared in a Christian home.

elt.selection: Attended Phillips Andover Academy from 1872 to 1875; then to Middlebury College, Vermont, 1875 to 1880; Boston University, 1880 to 1883.
lines: I went from Virginia to Vermont December 23,
1863. I worked on the farm nine months during the
year and attended common school three months.
I did this till 1872. I then went to Andover,
Massachusetts, March 7, 1872. <tspan class="underline">Attended</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Phillips Andover Academy from 1872 to 1875;</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">then to Middlebury College, Vermont, 1875 to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">1880; Boston University, 1880 to 1883</tspan>.

elt.selection: My early training was two months of public school each year and studying at night by lightwood knots.
lines: My early life was spent on the farm. <tspan class="underline">My</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">early training was two months of public school</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">each year and studying at night by lightwood</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">knots</tspan>. I went from this to the graded
school of Wilson, North Carolina, and from
there to Lincoln University, Pennsylvania.

elt.selection: I went to night school in the town where I was being reared by a family of white people who were the ex-owners of my parents
lines: I was born of poor, hard-working parents and was
left an orphan at eleven years. <tspan class="underline">I went to night</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">school in the town where I was being reared by a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">family of white people who were the ex-owners of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">my parents</tspan>. I entered school as a day student
at age of seventeen, completed the academic
course at twenty and then went to college.

elt.selection: My literary training was obtained in Tennessee, to which I was brought in very early life.
lines: Being born a slave, my early training was
quite meagre until I was eleven or twelve
years old, having simply learned to read
and spell well up to my twelfth year. <tspan class="underline">My</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">literary training was obtained in Tennessee,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to which I was brought in very early life.</tspan>

elt.selection: My early life was one of poverty and longing for better things
lines: <tspan class="underline">My early life was one of poverty</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and longing for better things</tspan>.

elt.selection: peddled wood at the Fayetteville, North Carolina, market many a winter with no shoes on and clothing extremely scarce. . . .
lines: I was born on a farm and remained there until
I was well up in age. I have chopped cotton,
worked corn, pulled hay, because I had no scythe
to cut it, peddled wood at the Fayetteville,
North Carolina, market many a winter with no
shoes on and clothing extremely scarce. . . . My
life was one of struggle from the time I could
remember but in the future I saw a star of hope
and pushed in that direction every time I saw
an opportunity to advance. I went to a country
school in a log house in Cumberland county,
North Carolina. I went to Wilmington to live and
there went to night school four or five months.

elt.selection: She was very kind to me and did laundry work that I might be allowed to attend school.
lines: My father deserted home when I was about five
years old. My mother died when I was twelve
years old, leaving me in the care of an
illiterate foster mother. <tspan class="underline">She was very kind</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to me and did laundry work that I might be</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">allowed to attend school.</tspan> I finished the
public school course in 1895. In the summer of
1896 I went to Rhode Island to work. From that
time until I finished school in 1905 1 paid my
own expenses by doing hotel work in summer.

elt.selection: I learned the alphabet in 1868 near Nashville, Tennessee, and graduated from college in 1878.
lines: I was born a slave. <tspan class="underline">I learned the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">alphabet in 1868 near Nashville, Tennessee,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and graduated from college in 1878.</tspan>

elt.selection: Early life on a plantation amid surroundings incident to slave life. Attended public school more or less irregularly
lines: <tspan class="underline">Early life on a plantation amid surroundings</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">incident to slave life. Attended public</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">school more or less irregularly</tspan>.

elt.selection: I was a slave until eleven years of age. I learned the bricklayer's trade. I entered college in l875.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was a slave until eleven years</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of age. I learned the bricklayer's</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">trade. I entered college in l875.</tspan>

elt.selection: I was born in the country, worked on farm till eighteen years old, then worked for railroad three years.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was born in the country, worked on farm</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">till eighteen years old, then worked for</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">railroad three years. </tspan>I went to school
about four months before I was twenty.

elt.selection: I never had the support of a father but was obedient to the direction of a loving mother to whom I owe all I am and all I hope to be.
lines: I passed my early life on the farm near the town
of Franklinton, North Carolina, and was trained
in the Christian Institute and Albion Academy.<tspan class="underline"></tspan>
<tspan class="underline">I never had the support of a father but was</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">obedient to the direction of a loving mother to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">whom I owe all I am and all I hope to be.</tspan>

elt.selection: I worked on a farm and attended rural schools until I was sixteen and then entered Fisk University.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I worked on a farm and attended</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">rural schools until I was sixteen and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">then entered Fisk University.</tspan>

elt.selection: I was born a slave and was freed by the Emancipation Proclamation of Abraham Lincoln.
lines: I was born a slave and was freed by the
Emancipation Proclamation of Abraham Lincoln.

elt.selection: I lived then with white people, working for my board and clothes several years.
lines: I went to a private school when quite young. My
father and mother died when I was nine years old.
<tspan class="underline">I lived then with white people, working for my</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">board and clothes several years. </tspan>While there
I lacked one year of completing the high school
course. I went from there to Lincoln Institute
and completed the two years' Normal course. From
Lincoln Institute I went to Fisk University
and completed the bachelor of arts course.

elt.selection: I was born on a sugar plantation; spent early life as a farmer.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was born on a sugar plantation; spent</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">early life as a farmer. </tspan>I had some
advantages of public school instruction.

elt.selection: I pushed my own way forward mostly, i. e. with the occasional lift my father would give when I called upon him
lines: I assisted my father on the farm and in his winter
work as the town butcher during school vacations
in the summer and on Saturdays. I attended the
public schools of Macon, Mississippi, during
their sessions of nine months. I was taught
first by those whites who came from the North
as teachers during the seventies; then by Fisk
and Rust University graduates until I came to
Fisk in 1887. <tspan class="underline">I pushed my own way forward</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">mostly, i. e. with the occasional lift my father</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">would give when I called upon him</tspan>, which I
reluctantly did as he evidently had succeeded
some in his teaching of self-reliance-not
running up the white flag upon every occasion.

elt.selection: I was born on my father's farm in the traditional log cabin.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was born on my father's farm in the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">traditional log cabin. </tspan>Early training
was received in the country public school.

elt.selection: In 1876 1 got desperate and broke away from my family and entered Storr's School.
lines: My childhood and youth were spent in Atlanta.
Most of my time I was working to help support
my family. Now and then I went to night school
and the summer country school. <tspan class="underline">In 1876 1</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">got desperate and broke away from my family</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and entered Storr's School.</tspan> Finishing
there in the spring of 1877, in the fall of
the same year I entered Atlanta University and
there I remained till I was graduated in 1884.

elt.selection: My people were free, able to read and write, and with a knowledge of refinement above the average
lines: I was eighteen months old, the youngest of six
children, when my Father died. My mother was
left with a home and six children too young to
work. Having nothing left me and with brothers
and sisters to be supported by my mother, my
early life was one of denial. I had the necessary
things of life-nothing else. When I became old
enough to work I secured a route on an afternoon
paper and sold papers Sunday mornings. I did
this all the time I was attending school in this
city, making from one and a half to three and a
half dollars per week. <tspan class="underline">My people were free,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">able to read and write, and with a knowledge</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of refinement above the average</tspan>, therefore
my home surroundings were above the average.
I had a good training along religious lines.

elt.selection: During vacations and holidays I worked in the shop with my father who was a wheelwright and wagon and carriage builder.
lines: <tspan class="underline">During vacations and holidays I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">worked in the shop with my father who</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">was a wheelwright and wagon and carriage</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">builder.</tspan> I worked some with an uncle on
the farm when work in the shop was slack.

elt.selection: From 1867 to 1880 I was in school in Atlanta, Georgia, and Andover, Massachusetts.
lines: I was born in slavery and came into freedom
under the terms of Lincoln's Emancipation
Proclamation. While a slave I did various kinds
of light work for my master's family or for
other white people to whom I was often hired.
From 1865 to 1867 I tried to help my mother
support her large family of children. <tspan class="underline">From</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">1867 to 1880 I was in school in Atlanta,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Georgia, and Andover, Massachusetts.</tspan>

elt.selection: I worked on farm with my father until I was fifteen; then a few months on the railroad
lines: Beginning at the age of six I attended the country
district school, terms averaging about two and
one-half months per year. <tspan class="underline">I worked on farm</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">with my father until I was fifteen; then a few</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">months on the railroad</tspan>; but my chief work up
to the age of twenty-one was in tobacco factories.

elt.selection: I worked at any and all kinds of common work, such as waiting table and barber shop porter
lines: <tspan class="underline">I worked at any and all kinds of common work,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">such as waiting table and barber shop porter</tspan>,
attending the common schools and also taking
advantage of such private schools as were offered.

elt.selection: I learned to read and write in night school in Albany, Georgia, in 1866
lines: I was sixteen when the war closed. <tspan class="underline">I learned</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to read and write in night school in Albany,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Georgia, in 1866</tspan>. I plowed all day and
walked a mile and a half at night to school.

elt.selection: When I was eight years old I walked with my parents to Kanawha county, West Virginia, a distance of two hundred and fifty miles
lines: I was born a slave on a farm in Franklin
county, Virginia. <tspan class="underline">When I was eight years</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">old I walked with my parents to Kanawha</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">county, West Virginia, a distance of two</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">hundred and fifty miles</tspan>, in the month of
March. My father died when I was twelve. I
never attended school until after that time.

elt.selection: I had about nine months of schooling before reaching the age of twenty-one years
lines: I was a slave until I reached the age of
thirteen years. I was taken from my parents
at ten years of age. I have been compelled to
support myself since 1865. <tspan class="underline">I had about nine</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">months of schooling before reaching the age of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">twenty-one years</tspan>. I have received most of my
education since I became twenty-one years of age.

elt.selection: I acted as a clerk in a supply department at a summer resort for eighteen years during summer vacations while a student
lines: I was born and reared on a farm, attended the
country schools during my boyhood days. I have
done all kinds of laboring work, both on the
farm and on the railroad. <tspan class="underline">I acted as a clerk</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">in a supply department at a summer resort for</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">eighteen years during summer vacations while</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a student</tspan> and since I have been teaching.

elt.selection: I had to work for what I could eat and wear, having no one to help me in life.
lines: I was brought up on a farm with no chance to
educate myself. <tspan class="underline">I had to work for what I could</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">eat and wear, having no one to help me in life.</tspan>
<tspan class="underline"></tspan>Father was dead; mother could not help me
because she was not able. I had no chance to
go to school until I was nineteen years old.

elt.selection: I was naturally studious. I studied Latin and Algebra myself.
lines: I jobbed around in summer and attended winter
school, maintained by my parents; taught generally
by students from Oberlin College. I was hired out
as house-boy for a while; carried clothes back
and forth as my mother took in washing. <tspan class="underline">I was</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">naturally studious. I studied Latin and Algebra</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">myself. </tspan>I went to Louisville, Kentucky, before
the war and assisted my brother-in-law in teaching
free Negro children and slaves who could get a
permit. From there I went to Ohio University,
Athens, Ohio, in 1849 and graduated there in 1853.

elt.selection: I was educated largely by my own efforts, being left an orphan in the state of Vermont after 1865.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was educated largely by my own</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">efforts, being left an orphan in the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">state of Vermont after 1865.</tspan>

elt.selection: At the end of the school term I passed the fourth grade, the proudest boy in the world.
lines: My mother died when I was six months old,
father when I was seven years old. Between the
city and country I lived, survived and did not
perish. At the age of nineteen I was janitor
of graded school in Durham, North Carolina. I
received ten dollars per month and my schooling.
<tspan class="underline">At the end of the school term I passed</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the fourth grade, the proudest boy in the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">world.</tspan> I clerked in store that summer and
in the fall I entered Fisk with a vim to win.

elt.selection: I was taught at nights by the daughters of the man to whom I was apprenticed for four years.
lines: I was born a slave. I was bound out for four
years. I was taught at nights by the daughters
of the man to whom I was apprenticed for
four years. Lived and worked on farm most
of the time till nineteen years of age.

elt.selection: I attended two months during session for four years. Meanwhile I continued to burn the midnight oil.
lines: I was born a slave and left an orphan. I was sent
adrift empty hand without parents or guardian.
I began education in night school. I entered
day school under Quakers at age of seventeen.
<tspan class="underline">I attended two months during session for</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">four years. Meanwhile I continued to burn the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">midnight oil.</tspan> I became clerk, bookkeeper,
deputy sheriff, policeman, public school teacher.

elt.selection: I attended public schools of Augusta, Georgia, and worked between times as a newspaper carrier and later on as a printer.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I attended public schools of Augusta,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Georgia, and worked between times as a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">newspaper carrier and later on as a printer.</tspan>
<tspan class="underline"></tspan>I was graduated from Ware High School in
1886 and then entered Atlanta University.

elt.selection: I grew up on a farm with a 'scrapped up' education in fitful public and private schools and private instruction.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I grew up on a farm with a 'scrapped</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">up' education in fitful public and private</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">schools and private instruction.</tspan>

elt.selection: My early life and training was that of the ordinary youth of our race: one of a large family of children, on a little farm
lines: <tspan class="underline">My early life and training was that of the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">ordinary youth of our race: one of a large</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">family of children, on a little farm</tspan>, a
few months' attendance every year at public
schools until large enough to work. At the
age of twenty I left for the North and by
hard work by day and private study by night
I prepared to enter Lincoln University.

elt.selection: I was born a slave and was a farm boy until twenty-four years old.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was born a slave and was a farm</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">boy until twenty-four years old.</tspan>

elt.selection: I learned my A, B, C's from the Bible in my tenth year. I had two terms of school
lines: I was born in the country in Missouri. Up to
nine years of age I had no schooling. <tspan class="underline">I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">learned my A, B, C's from the Bible in my tenth</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">year. I had two terms of school</tspan>, one three
months, one five months in Missouri. My family
emigrated to Nebraska when I was in my twelfth
year. Farmed there and finished common and high
school at Seward, Seward county, Nebraska.

elt.selection: I was a farm boy until twenty-four years of age. I was born a slave.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was a farm boy until twenty-four</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">years of age. I was born a slave.</tspan>

elt.selection: Sea life for eight or ten years. I traveled much.
lines: <tspan class="underline">Sea life for eight or ten years. I traveled</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">much.</tspan> I attended district school in
Massachusetts in winter. My academic training
was received at Pierce Academy, Middleboro,
Massachusetts; college work at Atlanta University.

elt.selection: I made a good average with attendance daily the first term and was promoted. The next term I became tutor.
lines: I attended public school in a rural district
until sixteen years old. I then went to a
small town and entered graded school. <tspan class="underline">I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">made a good average with attendance daily the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">first term and was promoted. The next term I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">became tutor.</tspan> My parents being dead my
teachers became interested in me and made it
possible for me to enter college in 1893.

elt.selection: Steady work and interested parties put me thru school.
lines: I was reared on the farm until old enough
to earn wages; then I was hired out until
about twenty years old, when I entered school
for the first time. <tspan class="underline">Steady work and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">interested parties put me thru school.</tspan>

elt.selection: My parents were poor yet they kept me supplied with books and saw to it that I attended our rural school regularly.
lines: I was reared on a farm. <tspan class="underline">My parents were poor</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">yet they kept me supplied with books and saw to it</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">that I attended our rural school regularly.</tspan> At
the age of fourteen I entered Tougaloo University.

elt.selection: knowing the advantage of an education they spent a fortune in educating their children, giving thirteen-all who did not die in early childhood-a fair English training
lines: I was reared on a large farm owned by my father,
who was one of the most extensive cotton planters
in Ouachita Parish. My parents were not educated
but both could read and write; and <tspan class="underline">knowing the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">advantage of an education they spent a fortune</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">in educating their children, giving thirteen-all</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">who did not die in early childhood-a fair English</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">training</tspan>. When I was nine years of age
they employed a tutor in the home to prepare
me to be sent off to school, since educational
advantages for Negroes were so poor in that part
of the state. The next year I entered Straight.

elt.selection: I was born in a cabin and attended a country school.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was born in a cabin and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">attended a country school.</tspan>

elt.selection: I had every opportunity and encouragement to acquire an education.
lines: The child of a college-bred mother and fairly
intelligent father, my home life and early
training were good; <tspan class="underline">I had every opportunity</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and encouragement to acquire an education.</tspan>

elt.selection: My mother was a skilled dressmaker who served for Mrs. President Polk and others high in social life.
lines: I had a good home and intelligent parents,
who were free people before the war, hence I
enjoyed some educational advantages before
the Civil War. My father was a barber and a
lawyer, the first colored man admitted to the
bar in Tennessee. <tspan class="underline">My mother was a skilled</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">dressmaker who served for Mrs. President</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Polk and others high in social life.</tspan>

elt.selection: I attended the public school of Oberlin, Ohio, for two years.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I attended the public school of Oberlin,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Ohio, for two years.</tspan> We moved South
in 1883. From then I was taught in the
home until I went off to school in 1890.

elt.selection: During each school year I earned my board entirely by services rendered in the president's family.
lines: I was a pupil in the public school of Gainesville,
Florida, until about sixteen years of age. Then I
entered the State Normal School at Tallahassee,
Florida, from which I graduated in 1902. While
a student at Tallahassee I taught each summer
in rural schools. <tspan class="underline">During each school year I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">earned my board entirely by services rendered</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">in the president's family. </tspan>After graduating
I taught two consecutive terms in city schools
and in 1904 spent the summer studying at the
University of Chicago. In the fall of 1904 1
returned South and entered Clark University.

elt.selection: I was educated in Iowa. I earned my way thru the University.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I was educated in Iowa. I earned</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">my way thru the University.</tspan>

elt.selection: My father was a man of fair education; mother not formally educated but a great reader from her youth up.
lines: <tspan class="underline">My father was a man of fair education;</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">mother not formally educated but a great reader</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">from her youth up.</tspan> Both were actively
interested in the education of their children.

cedu.selection: It is my present intention to give my boys a full university training in order that they may be equipped to take high rank
lines: <tspan class="underline">It is my present intention to give my boys</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a full university training in order that they</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">may be equipped to take high rank</tspan> in
whatever calling or profession they may choose.

cedu.selection: I believe in educating the child to make the best citizen; a college education to those who will take it.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I believe in educating the child</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to make the best citizen; a college</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">education to those who will take it.</tspan>

cedu.selection: If then any offspring from my household manifest special taste for and high merit in any worthy line, I shall only ask God to enable me to assist them
lines: In obedience to their inclinations and gifts and
without prejudice for or against any particular
training. Technical, agricultural, mercantile,
professional training are of equal importance
if preparation and research are sufficient,
there being urgent need for real high grade
leadership in every avenue for the Negro. <tspan class="underline">If</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">then any offspring from my household manifest</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">special taste for and high merit in any worthy</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">line, I shall only ask God to enable me to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">assist them</tspan> to the highest in that line.

cedu.selection: I shall teach the importance of attainment of the highest possible type of culture and refinement
lines: First public school, secondly college, third
university, then if possible provide for
her to study abroad. <tspan class="underline">I shall teach the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">importance of attainment of the highest</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">possible type of culture and refinement</tspan>
and the importance of possessing something
that people who have money want.

cedu.selection: I have but one daughter. I plan to give her a college education in southern, eastern and European institutions.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I have but one daughter. I plan to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">give her a college education in southern,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">eastern and European institutions.</tspan>

cedu.selection: I am striving to be in shape to give my children a thoro, practical education
lines: <tspan class="underline">I am striving to be in shape to give my</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">children a thoro, practical education</tspan> which
will best fit them for the daily pursuits of life.

cedu.selection: I shall endeavor to give that training which in my judgment will be of the highest good to him.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I shall endeavor to give that</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">training which in my judgment will</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">be of the highest good to him.</tspan>

cedu.selection: I want my daughter to make music her specialty but will allow her to choose her literary course.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I want my daughter to make music</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">her specialty but will allow her</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to choose her literary course.</tspan>

cedu.selection: Two or three may take the university course, one in music, one in theology.
lines: Each is to receive at least a normal and academic
education. <tspan class="underline">Two or three may take the university</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">course, one in music, one in theology.</tspan>

cedu.selection: It is my intention to give them the very best education that they can assimilate.
lines: <tspan class="underline">It is my intention to give them the very</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">best education that they can assimilate.</tspan>

cedu.selection: I shall teach them the fundamentals of politeness, hygiene, and the art of doing work assigned them smoothly and with polish.
lines: I desire to have them brought up at a school
such as Fisk after they have reached puberty
and later at a northern university. But first
of all <tspan class="underline">I shall teach them the fundamentals</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of politeness, hygiene, and the art of doing</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">work assigned them smoothly and with polish.</tspan>

cedu.selection: The education of my children will probably depend largely upon their own wishes
lines: <tspan class="underline">The education of my children will probably</tspan>

white man in this country, <tspan class="underline">the young men of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">our race are neglecting opportunities which would</tspan>

<tspan class="underline">wayside</tspan>. Prejudice and lack of opportunity:

hind.selection: Poor salary.
lines: <tspan class="underline"><tspan class="underline">Poor salary.</tspan> Prejudice on</tspan>

<tspan class="underline">heavy obligations since leaving school.</tspan>

my advancement. <tspan class="underline">I have never been able to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">receive pay adequate to my qualifications.</tspan>

<tspan class="underline">things which would tend to advancement</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">for white men have been overlooked</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">in my case on account of color.</tspan>

lines: The same every colored man meets. <tspan class="underline">Menial</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">positions; poor pay as a teacher; fidelity</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to my race, which led me to decline a high</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">position on a railroad in Georgia which I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">could have had by passing for white. </tspan>I
could get only about two-thirds the salary

With me it has been more of a stimulus.

<tspan class="underline">and forced me to accept less pay for the</tspan>

<tspan class="underline">than my white comrades.</tspan> No incentive

have been prevented from reaching that prominence

because he knows the honors and emoluments of

race. No matter what his excellence or fitness

<tspan class="underline">of activities for broader culture</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and for increased efficiency.</tspan>

hind.selection: Race prejudice has undoubtedly lessened my opportunities but on the other hand has served indirectly to make me use such opportunities

<tspan class="underline">opportunities but on the other hand has served</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">indirectly to make me use such opportunities</tspan>
as I have had to a better advantage than

lines: Lack of means to procure needed facilities to
carry out and plan my line of work for myself
and for my pupils. A desire on the part of
school boards to restrict us in our efforts to
secure a sufficient number of, and capable,
efficient teachers, well equipped laboratories and
libraries. <tspan class="underline">I taught physics and chemistry in</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a laboratory in --- furnished by ourselves.</tspan>

hind.selection: n some places silent opposition to Negro college graduates on the part of white and colored.

graduates on the part of white and colored.

hind.selection: Prejudice is always present but I have found far more opportunity than prejudice

<tspan class="underline">far more opportunity than prejudice</tspan>, i. e.
prejudice that hindered in any vital sense.
The greatest hindrance is the indifference
of my own people to the necessity for unity

Prejudice has made me work harder and so has
proved many times a blessing in disguise.

hind.selection: It is my belief that prejudice is a spur to serious endeavor on the part of intelligent colored men.

<tspan class="underline">a spur to serious endeavor on the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">part of intelligent colored men.</tspan>

<tspan class="underline">to my disadvantage to the extent of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">cooling ardor and chilling aspiration.</tspan>

lines: <tspan class="underline">Prejudice and lack of opportunity have</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">retarded my progress but by industry,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">economy, conservatism and perseverance</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">I have in a measure overcome them</tspan>.

hind.selection: Prejudice against the higher education of Negroes.
lines: <tspan class="underline">Prejudice against the higher</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">education of Negroes.</tspan>

<tspan class="underline">many superior minds.</tspan> It has denied me the

opportunity. <tspan class="underline">There is not enough business</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">among colored people to employ their young</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">men and women when they finish school.</tspan>

hind.selection: No man who has been hampered by or has been compelled to contend against prejudice has been able to reach his best and biggest self.
lines: It is hard to specify the ways in which
prejudice has worked against one. <tspan class="underline">No man</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">who has been hampered by or has been compelled</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to contend against prejudice has been able</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to reach his best and biggest self.</tspan>

lines: Prejudice has been from the very beginning
the chief hindrance in my life. I have been
turned from printing establishments because of
objection to my color. <tspan class="underline">I have been engaged</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">for clerical work and then discharged when</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">my color became known.</tspan> It has operated
against me in oratorical contests at college.

hind.selection: I find the old adage holds true: Where there is a will there is a way
lines: I cannot complain of lack of opportunity.
<tspan class="underline">I find the old adage holds true: Where</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">there is a will there is a way</tspan>.

hind.selection: Prejudice has been no barrier when it came to acquiring property, but if often crushes my spirit.
lines: <tspan class="underline">Prejudice has been no barrier</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">when it came to acquiring property,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">but if often crushes my spirit.</tspan>

hind.selection: I have got what I went after, after a fight nevertheless, yet got it.
lines: In my estimation my chief hindrance has been that
I have never had all the equipment which I felt
should be mine to make the greatest possible
success in the tasks which have been mine. Tho
measurably successful in all my career I have
so often felt the need of more mastery over the
immediate problems of business. Prejudice has had
to do with my life and experience as with others.
Promotions which would have been given freely
and early to a man of another racial identity, I
have had to labor long for. Yet in all fairness
I must say that whereas prejudice, damnable and
low, is continually operating against me, yet I
have won so far. <tspan class="underline">I have got what I went after,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">after a fight nevertheless, yet got it.</tspan>

hind.selection: I cannot buy or rent respectable property without the greatest embarrassment and sometimes not even then.

<tspan class="underline">without the greatest embarrassment and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">sometimes not even then.</tspan> This gives
a set-back to my dignity and influence.

hind.selection: Prejudice has closed several doors of opportunity along the line of educational advantages
lines: <tspan class="underline">Prejudice has closed several doors of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">opportunity along the line of educational</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">advantages</tspan>; was responsible for a
low wage some years; and caused much
embarrassment in ways whose name is legion.

hind.selection: my chief hindrance has been my inability to play the hypocrite.

and vanity of the namby-pamby Negro. To put
it another way <tspan class="underline">my chief hindrance has</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">been my inability to play the hypocrite.</tspan>

hind.selection: Prejudice, I think, has made me suspicious of all white people, sometimes with injustice to them, I fear, and with injury to myself.

way of all college-bred Negro men who want
to make the most of life. <tspan class="underline">Prejudice, I</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">think, has made me suspicious of all white</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">people, sometimes with injustice to them,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">I fear, and with injury to myself.</tspan>

hind.selection: My chief hindrance is that I am deprived of the enjoyment of my rights as a free citizen.
lines: <tspan class="underline">My chief hindrance is that I am deprived of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the enjoyment of my rights as a free citizen.</tspan>

hind.selection: I feel that only half the measure of the possibilities of my career has been filled
