<tspan class="underline">possibilities of my career has been filled</tspan>
because prejudice has been a handicap to the full
and free prosecution of my professional labors.
Most of the Negros believe that to succeed in
our efforts they must have a white advocate.

hind.selection: There is in this community a kindly growing sentiment on the part of the whites toward colored people and so prejudice does not interrupt much
lines: <tspan class="underline">There is in this community a kindly</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">growing sentiment on the part of the whites</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">toward colored people and so prejudice does</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">not interrupt much</tspan>. My chief hindrance
is due to the fact that it is difficult to
get my own people to appreciate in a large
way our opportunities for growth and power.

hind.selection: we are coming to a better understanding of each other and business confidence in each other is being developed
lines: Lack of confidence among our people to intrust
their business with one another and to do
business with each other generally. I might
term it â€˜race pride.â€™ I think it is due more to
absolute ignorance. However,<tspan class="underline"> we are coming to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a better understanding of each other and business</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">confidence in each other is being developed</tspan>
both on account of oppression and prejudice and
the preaching of self-help among ourselves.

hind.selection: Expecting no quarter it has been with me a fight to the finish and a point of manhood and honor to succeed.
lines: Prejudice and lack of opportunity have been at
once my handicap and my constant stimulant.
Daily experience with them has kept me keyed
up to constant exertion and the doing of
my best. <tspan class="underline">Expecting no quarter it has</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">been with me a fight to the finish and a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">point of manhood and honor to succeed.</tspan>

hind.selection: Failure of the people - to appreciate real ability.
lines: Lack of proper aspiration among the
masses. <tspan class="underline">Failure of the people - to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">appreciate real ability.</tspan> Jealousy
and prejudice among certain leaders.

hind.selection: My greatest hindrance was lack of public school opportunity early in life.
lines: <tspan class="underline">My greatest hindrance was lack of public</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">school opportunity early in life.</tspan> A
lot of good time was lost in those days.

hind.selection: No man can do his best while hampered by senseless prejudice.
lines: Prejudice hinders a man all the time
and everywhere in doing a man's work.
<tspan class="underline">No man can do his best while</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">hampered by senseless prejudice.</tspan>

hind.selection: Prejudice of ignorant blacks as well as whites does a great deal to hinder.
lines: <tspan class="underline">Prejudice of ignorant blacks as well as</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">whites does a great deal to hinder.</tspan> The
uneducated black is very jealous of his educated
brother and will do lots to hinder his progress.

hind.selection: I have felt perhaps more than anything else the prohibition from public library facilities in such a city as Atlanta.
lines: In my work <tspan class="underline">I have felt perhaps more than</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">anything else the prohibition from public library</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">facilities in such a city as Atlanta.</tspan>

hind.selection: My chief hindrance has possibly come from within: the ignorance of the big opportunities that await the average young Negro man of education
lines: Prejudice has played so small a part that it can
be considered a negligible quantity. Perhaps I
have not followed the paths in which one would
meet it so keenly. <tspan class="underline">My chief hindrance has</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">possibly come from within: the ignorance of the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">big opportunities that await the average young</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Negro man of education</tspan> and energy in the
business world provided he works eternally.

hind.selection: Social conditions in my home state shut me out of the career I would have naturally sought there.
lines: A very limited field to choose positions from,
as compared to many of my white fellow students
whose academic standing was below mine. <tspan class="underline">Social</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">conditions in my home state shut me out of the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">career I would have naturally sought there.</tspan>

hind.selection: It has kept me alive and made me yearn to accomplish something, nerved me to live and endure suffering
lines: Prejudice has made me fight the harder to overcome
the disabilities of caste. <tspan class="underline">It has kept me</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">alive and made me yearn to accomplish something,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">nerved me to live and endure suffering</tspan>
and sorrow of any kind in order to see the
ultimate triumph of righteous civic ideals.

hind.selection: Rather difficult to answer as I have worked all the while under conditions that I saw little hope of changing
lines: <tspan class="underline">Rather difficult to answer as I have worked</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">all the while under conditions that I saw</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">little hope of changing</tspan> hence gave little
thot to what I might have done under different
conditions. I feel sure the lack of opportunity
for full exercise of ability in certain lines
has, perhaps in some cases unconsciously,
served to stifle ambition and prevent activity
that might have been useful to communities in
which I have lived. In some instances I think
prejudice has nerved me to more persistent effort.

hind.selection: The color line has prevented a chance for scientific and literary work.
lines: <tspan class="underline">The color line has prevented a chance</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">for scientific and literary work.</tspan>

hind.selection: No one is able to estimate the damage inflicted upon him by the forces which make for ostracism
lines: Race prejudice prevents me being retained as
counsel where otherwise I would be employed.
It keeps away the most remunerative class of
business. It compels me to accept a smaller fee
for work done and services rendered than would
otherwise be the case. It often causes me to
contest in court for fees after they have been
earned, when but for the â€˜previous condition of
servitudeâ€™ of my ancestors said fees would be
cheerfully paid. <tspan class="underline">No one is able to estimate</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the damage inflicted upon him by the forces</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">which make for ostracism</tspan> and which impose a
perennial and continued boycott because of race.

hind.selection: 3. The false notion that the Negro scholar does not deserve as much pay for intellectual work as a white man
lines: 1. Prejudice which debars me from work in
institutions for which my training fits me. 2.
Superficially trained Negroes who, like the
dog in the manger, have ever tried to hinder
my progress. <tspan class="underline">3. The false notion that the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Negro scholar does not deserve as much pay for</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">intellectual work as a white man</tspan> does for
the same work. 4. Poor salary which has made it
necessary for me to abandon many of my researches
at an early stage. Indeed what little I have
accomplished has been at the expense of the
comforts and often of the necessities of life.

pl.selection: The hope of the Negro is a Christian education of heart, head and hand.
lines: <tspan class="underline">The hope of the Negro is a Christian</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">education of heart, head and hand.</tspan>

pl.selection: He wants to be treated and regarded as an American citizen in fact.
lines: In my opinion the Negro needs nothing so much as
to be let alone. He wants not special attention
either in the legislative hall or out. <tspan class="underline">He</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">wants to be treated and regarded as an American</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">citizen in fact.</tspan> He asks for no more than
he merits but he wants all he does merit. To
reach this point he must contend for all the
term implies. Life is a battle and every man
must be a fighter. Playing the baby-act will not
accomplish anything. Brave men will not only
suffer hardships in maintaining their rights
but will face dangers. Long since I came to the
conclusion that right living on our part would not
alone solve the problem. It is not the worthless,
ignorant spendthrift among us that arouses the
white manâ€™s opposition, repression, oppression,
and prejudice. That class knows â€˜his place.â€™

pl.selection: There is an attempt in a large part of the country to establish a caste system of education for the Negro.
lines: I have an abiding hope for the future of the race.
But great suffering and loss are in store for the
race thru error. <tspan class="underline">There is an attempt in a large</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">part of the country to establish a caste system</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of education for the Negro.</tspan> . . . . In the
state institutions they are taking out the higher
studies and promoting mediocre men and women,
paying them in proportion much larger salaries
than they are paying college-bred Negro teachers.

pl.selection: I firmly believe that the destiny of the American Negro lies largely in his own hands.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I firmly believe that the destiny of the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">American Negro lies largely in his own hands.</tspan>
I have never yet seen a self-respecting, honest
and industrious Negro, educated or uneducated,
who did not have the respect and good-will of
the better class of whites with whom he comes in
contact. . . . I believe that we as individuals
must take as our weapons honesty, industry
and economy and wage a war against prejudice.

pl.selection: Tho race prejudice is rampant it is still too weak to suppress any class which has the determination to rise. There is still plenty of room.
lines: The Negro race in America is fortunate. The
country is still far from being developed or
crowded. <tspan class="underline">Tho race prejudice is rampant</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">it is still too weak to suppress any class</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">which has the determination to rise. There</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">is still plenty of room.</tspan> Less complaint
and more effort will pull us up with the
dominant class. We should seek and develop
all the thinly settled parts of this country.

pl.selection: The Negro must continue to contend for all the rights, privileges, and opportunities accorded other American citizens.
lines: <tspan class="underline">The Negro must continue to contend for all the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">rights, privileges, and opportunities accorded</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">other American citizens.</tspan> He must be unyielding
this respect. He ought to ally himself with any
political party that will further these ends.

pl.selection: we would do well to spend less time in finding fault and use that time preparing ourselves for larger activities and more usefulness.
lines: I feel that the Negro has many reasons to be
hopeful. Of course there are many things that
are deplorable; but on the other hand there
are so many opportunities already open to us
that we do not take advantage of that <tspan class="underline">we</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">would do well to spend less time in finding</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">fault and use that time preparing ourselves</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">for larger activities and more usefulness.</tspan>

pl.selection: My own confident hope is that there will be ultimately a satisfactory issue to all present race difficulties.
lines: <tspan class="underline">My own confident hope is that there</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">will be ultimately a satisfactory issue</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to all present race difficulties.</tspan>

pl.selection: The problem of the American Negro is difficult to solve upon a basis of perpetual segregation.
lines: I regard it as essential that political privileges
be granted to men regardless of color, the
same qualifications demanded of all in an
absolutely impartial manner. 1 regard education
as indispensable and believe in equal facilities
for it. . . . . <tspan class="underline">The problem of the American</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Negro is difficult to solve upon a basis of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">perpetual segregation.</tspan> It is particularly
desirable that there shall be no segregation in
the higher institutions of learning. Industrial
and manual activities should be elements in the
course of study for colored people as for all
people but not the only elements nor even the
principal ones. I think that the colored people
should be stimulated to acquire property and to
become fixed in their communities. In order that
this may happen it is necessary to secure for the
Negro greater protection of life and property.

pl.selection: With education and the right to voteâ€”for both of which the Negro must work and fight dailyâ€”he will win the place which is his here in America.
lines: <tspan class="underline">With education and the right to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">voteâ€”for both of which the Negro must</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">work and fight dailyâ€”he will win the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">place which is his here in America.</tspan>

pl.selection: an all-controlling desire to stick to the right, will not only win for the Negro the respect of America but will give him a place immortal in the history of the world.
lines: Persistent, definite and determined effort along
all legitimate lines of education, coupled
with <tspan class="underline">an all-controlling desire to stick to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the right, will not only win for the Negro the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">respect of America but will give him a place</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">immortal in the history of the world.</tspan>

pl.selection: enable him to successfully compete with every other element of Americanism in every walk of life
lines: Educate him in the highest and best
way possible so as to <tspan class="underline">enable him to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">successfully compete with every other element</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of Americanism in every walk of life</tspan>.

pl.selection: First train the mind; then in order to be highly regarded by Americans own some of the worldâ€™s goods.
lines: The accumulation of property will do more to
relieve the American Negro of many hardships and
disadvantages than any other agency. This should
not be the case but it is. The ability to think
well (generally the result of thoro training)
should outrank the ability to live well (the
result of accumulated wealth). <tspan class="underline">First train</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the mind; then in order to be highly regarded</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">by Americans own some of the worldâ€™s goods.</tspan>

pl.selection: The Negro race would be much stronger if there were more who could see the benefit of a college education
lines: <tspan class="underline">The Negro race would be much stronger if</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">there were more who could see the benefit</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of a college education</tspan>, be it in the
professional line or in trade. I think
the higher education of the Negro race
will tend towards reducing race prejudice.

pl.selection: 7. The Negro should be urged to content peaceably and earnestly for everything that is needed to make him a man.
lines: 1. The Negro must be an active voter. 2. He must
be encouraged to engage in what he is by nature
fitted to follow, this not to be determined by
one man or set of men but by the individual. 3.
He should study the conditions of his community
and enter such activities as he can. He should
strive to establish himself in every line of
business possible. 4. He should study mining and
manufacturing. He should become an intelligent
farmer, vegetable raiser and cotton producer. 5.
He should be more thoroly grounded in mechanics
that he may become an inventor. Our colleges
could look out for this. There should be no
cheap course in mechanics. 6. Our schools and
other institutions should teach everything that
is necessary to make the pupils serviceable
and life enjoyable. <tspan class="underline">7. The Negro should be</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">urged to content peaceably and earnestly for</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">everything that is needed to make him a man.</tspan>

pl.selection: The Negro is passing through a critical period of his existence in America
lines: <tspan class="underline">The Negro is passing through a critical</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">period of his existence in America</tspan> and no
one can say with certainty what the result will
be. To my mind, however, it is clear that he
will come out with a loss of political power and
interest, but greatly strengthened in wealth,
intelligence, and manhood which will ultimately
force political recognition and consideration
and the full enjoyment of civil rights. The
Negro is undergoing a refining and hardening
process which tho humiliating and painful will
in the end make him stronger and better and will
prove a blessing to him and to his posterity.

pl.selection: If the Negro is given protection and an equal opportunity in the industrial world he will succeed as a race.
lines: <tspan class="underline">If the Negro is given protection and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">an equal opportunity in the industrial</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">world he will succeed as a race.</tspan>

pl.selection: we shall ultimately build for ourselves character and accumulate wealth, a combination which merits and demands respect
lines: I think that with better rural schools, longer
terms, better teachers, a more practical education
for the masses and a higher and more thoro
education for the leaders, more effective and
aggressive religious training with a practical
religion that we live and not simply talk
and shout, <tspan class="underline">we shall ultimately build for</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">ourselves character and accumulate wealth, a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">combination which merits and demands respect</tspan>.
This done the future will take care of itself.

pl.selection: As he labors he should link himself to every movement for the betterment of the social and economic life of the community in which he casts his lot.
lines: I believe the Negro should secure all the training
the American school system, public and private,
can give. He should then enter some occupation,
business or professional, for which he seems
fitted individually regardless of tradition
or prejudice. <tspan class="underline">As he labors he should link</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">himself to every movement for the betterment of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the social and economic life of the community in</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">which he casts his lot.</tspan> He should preserve
a manly, courageous attitude on all questions
pertaining to the Suture of his race to the
end that the traditional ideals of his people
become a significant and serviceable factor in
American civilization. He must seek to show that
his uplift, political, social and religious,
is necessary to the progress of all America.

pl.selection: He should qualify himself politically as well as otherwise and become interested in all questions affecting humanity
lines: The Negro should occupy and improve every
worthy position attainable. In a manly and
honorable way he should protest against any
racial discrimination shown against him. He
should study carefully his white neighbor
and strive in every honest way to live in
harmony with him. <tspan class="underline">He should qualify</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">himself politically as well as otherwise and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">become interested in all questions affecting</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">humanity</tspan> in general and himself in particular.

pl.selection: The Negro American must he accorded absolute social and political equality and all the rights guaranteed under a pure democracy.
lines: The ideal must be reached after: not on the
basis of color or race or any such physical
divisions or distinctions, but on the basis
of humanity. Only by the way of frank, full,
free opportunities can we hope for the ideal.
<tspan class="underline">The Negro American must he accorded absolute</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">social and political equality and all the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">rights guaranteed under a pure democracy.</tspan>

pl.selection: Diversification in education and pursuit is necessary if a people is to be of the highest good to the country.
lines: All kinds of activities are essential to
the growth and proper development of a
people. <tspan class="underline">Diversification in education</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and pursuit is necessary if a people is to</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">be of the highest good to the country.</tspan>

pl.selection: Retention of the right of suffrage and the display of more independence in the matter of voting.
lines: Strong, well-trained leadership for the masses.
Educational opportunities unrestricted for
all as the case may demand. <tspan class="underline">Retention of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">the right of suffrage and the display of more</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">independence in the matter of voting.</tspan> A
better trained ministry to inculcate sound moral
teaching. The organizing in cities of clubs
for civic improvement and for demanding better
grammar school training for Negro children and
for teaching the masses, as far as possible,
the proper meaning and duties of citizenship.

pl.selection: Vigorously opposing the doctrine of servility and submission-but not service.
lines: Encouraging business enterprises. <tspan class="underline">Vigorously</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">opposing the doctrine of servility and</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">submission-but not service.</tspan> Co-operation as
far as possible and wherever warranted with fair
and right-minded whites for civic improvement.

pl.selection: he will eventually climb as high and accomplish as much as any race or people has accomplished
lines: If the Negro is given a chance and equal rights
as a citizen -<tspan class="underline">he will eventually climb as high</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and accomplish as much as any race or people has</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">accomplished</tspan>. A college training is not had
for him nor does it unfit him for usefulness as
is often said; but he is better able to meet
the demands and responsibilities of the times.

pl.selection: the Negro will some day become a big factor in the political life of the nation and occupy an enviable place in the economic development of the United States
lines: In spite of the evidences of prejudice everywhere
in our country, I believe that <tspan class="underline">the Negro will</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">some day become a big factor in the political life</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of the nation and occupy an enviable place in the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">economic development of the United States</tspan>.
He has already made a marvelous record-a record
that should give every man with Negro blood
in his veins the highest hope for the future.

pl.selection: I believe that the American Negro must live and die in America. Africa is not his home
lines: <tspan class="underline">I believe that the American Negro must</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">live and die in America. Africa is not his</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">home </tspan>for he would be an absolute stranger
there. I believe in the ultimate triumph of
right. I believe that we will receive our
rights and be given full citizenship when we as
a people demand the same 3rd not until then.

pl.selection: he will eventually come into his own and be fully recognized as an American citizen
lines: If the Negro will be wise and educate himself in
the trades and the professions, get homes and
own land and build up a strong moral character,
<tspan class="underline">he will eventually come into his own and be</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">fully recognized as an American citizen</tspan>.

pl.selection: He must deport himself as a man and he must insist on being treated as a man in America.
lines: The Negro must work and fight and fight and
work. He must scorn peace earned at the price
of his self-respect. <tspan class="underline">He must deport himself</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">as a man and he must insist on being treated</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">as a man in America.</tspan> Much time must be
given to the bettering of his environment so
that he can will to his children far better
surroundings than he himself has inherited.
Finally, he must cultivate more of the religion
of self-respect and less of the religion of fear.

pl.selection: The Negro should be given every opportunity and encouraged to get the very best education possible
lines: <tspan class="underline">The Negro should be given every opportunity</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and encouraged to get the very best education</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">possible</tspan>-college education in every possible
case before entering a professional school.
I think Negroes should enter professions and
trades, after college, after tastes lead them
and wherever there is likely to be a demand for
such professions and trades. They should own
homes and acquire additional property as much
as they can. They should have a better educated
ministry and more thoroly trained teachers.

pl.selection: We must produce a substantial capitalist class. Such a state of economy admits of a leisure class.
lines: I think that full political rights and a more
modified social code may be inaugurated in the
future. These higher attainments are not possible
until the Negro catches the true spirit of the
commercial age in which he lives and lays an
economic substructure as his foundation. <tspan class="underline">We</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">must produce a substantial capitalist class.</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Such a state of economy admits of a leisure</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">class.</tspan> If this leisure class is composed
of persons who are cultured, thrifty and
energetic I see no reason why full, political
rights should not be attained and a widely
modified social code substituted for the sham
of ignorance under which we are now living. I
think education can help ameliorate conditions.

pl.selection: A right-about-face with regard to the matter of the education of the youth of our race; that is, less industrialism and more intelligence.
lines: A leadership more broadly educated. An intelligent
and consistent agitation for the securing of our
citizenship rights. A manly stand in all things
pertaining to civil, social and moral questions.
<tspan class="underline">A right-about-face with regard to the matter</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of the education of the youth of our race; that</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">is, less industrialism and more intelligence.</tspan>

pl.selection: I most strenuously urge that our people, all of them, get the best possible training in the best colleges and universities of the country
lines: <tspan class="underline">I most strenuously urge that our people,</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">all of them, get the best possible training</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">in the best colleges and universities of the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">country</tspan> and affiliate with all the forces
and organizations making for the moral and
religious development of all the people.
In the meantime, I would add, encourage in
every way possible all the organizations
for the material growth of the country.

pl.selection: Wherever our people congregate in large numbers there very soon begins the agitation for disfranchisement.
lines: Undoubtedly prejudice is increasing rather than
diminishing. This has been brought to our minds
more forcibly by the passage of the 'grandfather
clause' amendment to the constitution of this
state. We who are here in Oklahoma feel that
colonization has brought it about as much as
anything. <tspan class="underline">Wherever our people congregate in</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">large numbers there very soon begins the agitation</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">for disfranchisement.</tspan> Were it possible for
the race to be widely diffused over the United
States, so that they might acquire wealth like the
so-called superior race, and be found only a few
in any one place, there would be no race problem.

pl.selection: the teaching of a saner and purer religion, performance of duties and a demand for all our rights under the law will bring a brighter day for the Negro in America
lines: I believe that the acquirement of education and
wealth, <tspan class="underline">the teaching of a saner and purer</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">religion, performance of duties and a demand</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">for all our rights under the law will bring</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a brighter day for the Negro in America</tspan>.

pl.selection: I believe that education coupled with a good moral and religious training will be the main factor
lines: <tspan class="underline">I believe that education coupled with</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a good moral and religious training</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">will be the main factor</tspan> in the
solution of the Negro problem in America.

pl.selection: I am rather an enthusiast on the return of a goodly portion of the Negroes to Africa as a final solution
lines: <tspan class="underline">I am rather an enthusiast on the return of</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">a goodly portion of the Negroes to Africa as a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">final solution</tspan>, by his voluntary and gradual
move as he realizes that he can hardly expect
to attain to a full measure of citizenship in
all that the word implies in this country.

pl.selection: The Negro will ever remain in America.
lines: <tspan class="underline"><tspan class="underline">The Negro will ever remain in America.</tspan></tspan>
Citizenship and opportunity will increase as the
Negro grows in stability, wealth and intelligence.
Prejudice will be forced to abate as slavery
recedes and the Negro acquires independence.

pl.selection: each will come to see that all must enjoy the same privileges
lines: I believe that as the Negro and the white
man are educated up to the truth of the
legal equality of all men under our American
government <tspan class="underline">each will come to see that all</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">must enjoy the same privileges</tspan>. Neither
is yet equal to the occasion. There are few
Negroes who are aggressive and demand, and
a few philanthropic whites who acknowledge
and concede equal opportunities for all men.

pl.selection: Every day gives us new evidences of the fact that he is becoming more appreciative of his right to life, liberty and property.
lines: The Negro is growing more assertive and
manly. <tspan class="underline">Every day gives us new evidences</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of the fact that he is becoming more</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">appreciative of his right to life, liberty</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and property.</tspan> He is beginning to meet
imposition with opposition, even with his life.

pl.selection: to become a citizen in the true sense he must enjoy the same opportunities and benefits as other citizens
lines: The Negro needs leaders and instructors who will
teach that he is a man and therefore must have all
the aids to the better life and good citizenship
that other men require; that <tspan class="underline">to become a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">citizen in the true sense he must enjoy the same</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">opportunities and benefits as other citizens</tspan>.

pl.selection: He must he taught not to close the door of hope upon himself, even in though he must be made to feel that competency must win
lines: The Negro must measure up to the standard of a man
in all respects if he hopes to gain what other
races have gained. Hence he must be impressed
with the necessity of preparing himself. The
young Negro must be inspired with reminders of
what other Negroes have accomplished. <tspan class="underline">He</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">must he taught not to close the door of hope</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">upon himself, even in though he must be made</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to feel that competency must win</tspan>, has won.

pl.selection: the outlook for the Negro race in America is bright or dark owing to the deportment of the Negro himself.
lines: To me, <tspan class="underline">the outlook for the Negro race</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">in America is bright or dark owing to the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">deportment of the Negro himself.</tspan> If he
will make use of the opportunities he has in
educating himself, saving his money, acquiring
property and in being a law-abiding citizen
there is no law that can successfully stop him.

pl.selection: Let him cease to be a cringing suppliant; assert his manhood intelligently; speak out against unjust discrimination and laws that affect him
lines: <tspan class="underline">Let him cease to be a cringing suppliant;</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">assert his manhood intelligently; speak out</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">against unjust discrimination and laws that</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">affect him</tspan>; demand a competent leadership
in pulpit, school training and politics; give
his children the highest possible training and
repudiate the stigma of being fit only for the
workshop; demand the rights guaranteed to citizens
by the Constitution; get property; migrate
from the South to all parts of the country.

pl.selection: The Negro came to America not by his own volition and is here to stay.
lines: <tspan class="underline">The Negro came to America not by his own</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">volition and is here to stay.</tspan> I believe he
should contend for all his rights as an American
citizen and enter all lines of competition
with the other races in this country.'

pl.selection: It is nonsense to expect perfect harmony between two races so situated as the Negroes and whites of America.
lines: The Negro in America should be educated just
as any other race in America. One phase of
education should not be too much emphasized
above another. All phases are necessary for the
highest realization of any race. Negroes should
demand their rights. <tspan class="underline">It is nonsense to expect</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">perfect harmony between two races so situated</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">as the Negroes and whites of America.</tspan> The
day which brings perfect harmony in America
must bring at the same time amalgamation.

pl.selection: The two things indispensable to the Negro's advance are money and education
lines: Persecution is a friend of progress. The very
things that are denied us we shall still
want-and we shall supply them ourselves.
Whatever community tries to keep the Negro down
must stay there with him. <tspan class="underline">The two things</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">indispensable to the Negro's advance are money</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and education</tspan>, both of which things are being
slowly but surely acquired by individuals and
by Negro communities. . . . . I have no doubt
that prejudice is growing but I do believe it
is a jealous prejudice and an outgrowth of the
desire to keep the Negro in a slave's position.

pl.selection: I believe that the ultimate solution of the race problem is amalgamation.
lines: <tspan class="underline">I believe that the ultimate solution</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">of the race problem is amalgamation.</tspan>

pl.selection: Nothing is worth having if it is not worth fighting for.
lines: We ought now to have all the rights and
privileges which are guaranteed by the Federal
Constitution. We must agitate and fight to
the last ditch for them. <tspan class="underline">Nothing is worth</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">having if it is not worth fighting for.</tspan>

pl.selection: the Negro in America will succeed and become a mighty power in the affairs of this country
lines: With the highest possible training, the
acquisition of property and the launching out
into all kinds of business enterprises, <tspan class="underline">the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">Negro in America will succeed and become a</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">mighty power in the affairs of this country</tspan>.

pl.selection: business enterprises of various kinds which will give employment to the average boy and girl of our race
lines: Industry, economy, obedience to all just
laws-in short, the same principles which are
helpful to any other race; morality, wealth and
education being big factors in the solution of
our problem; <tspan class="underline">business enterprises of various</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">kinds which will give employment to the average</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">boy and girl of our race</tspan>, allowing him to
aspire to the highest place in the business.

pl.selection: The Negro needs simply the proper training and a fair chance in the business world along with a square deal before the law
lines: <tspan class="underline">The Negro needs simply the proper training</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">and a fair chance in the business world along</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">with a square deal before the law</tspan> and he
will find a way or make one along by the side
of America's best citizens. We must insist
on a thoro education however. No limited
education in any particular will suffice.

pl.selection: The man who has no political rights has no way of protecting himself and family.
lines: The Negroes in America will never, develop to
the extent of their capacity, will never become
a great people, not even a free people, until
they have political rights equal to the white
race. <tspan class="underline">The man who has no political rights has</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">no way of protecting himself and family.</tspan>

pl.selection: In the present swift revolving scheme of industrial America, the right to vote is paramount.
lines: While he must give all due attention to his
duties, the Negro must not so act now or at
any time as to give the impression that he is
satisfied to give up even temporarily any of the
rights that belong to him as a man. <tspan class="underline">In the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">present swift revolving scheme of industrial</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">America, the right to vote is paramount.</tspan>

pl.selection: We are American citizens and should accept no treatment that does not apply equally to every other American citizen.
lines: The Negroes ought to have every right
guaranteed by the Constitution of the United
States. <tspan class="underline">We are American citizens and should</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">accept no treatment that does not apply</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">equally to every other American citizen.</tspan>

pl.selection: The Negro men who are really qualified to speak should take a bold, manly stand for the race.
lines: The masses should be trained in such a way as to
know well their rights and duties as citizens
and should be urged to faithfully perform
their duties and quietly, firmly, persistently
demand their rights. . . . . <tspan class="underline">The Negro</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">men who are really qualified to speak should</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">take a bold, manly stand for the race.</tspan>

pl.selection: The future of the Negro in this country will depend upon the kind of training given to the Negro youth.
lines: <tspan class="underline">The future of the Negro in this country</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">will depend upon the kind of training given</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">to the Negro youth.</tspan> The same kind of
training which has made other races great is
also necessary to make the Negro race great.

pl.selection: We must work, think and live independent of the dictates of those who regard us as less than other men.
lines: The Negro must become a part of all the life
about him. He must become Americanized in the
best and largest sense. He should be led out of
the consciousness that he must have anything
less than other citizens enjoy. All kinds of
education, all forms of wealth and a knowledge
of the ways of the American world are his needs
for this achievement. Each one of us must
refuse to turn from any avenue of life because
other men think it is not for Negroes. <tspan class="underline">We</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">must work, think and live independent of the</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">dictates of those who regard us as less than</tspan>
<tspan class="underline">other men.</tspan> The best of us should give of our
means, our time and ourselves to leaven the whole.
College-bred Negroes should live these ideas among
the masses and teach them to their children.
